comment: This is an extremely exhaustive course which should take a beginner at least 6 months to complete. I would recommend Balaguruswamy's JAVA or some other JAVA fundamentals book to be read first especially for absolute beginners. I was able to quickly grasp things because I have some back-ground in C++ and I also read a bit of what a class/ object is from the Oracle tutorials. In my opinion this 7 star course is very well supplemented by :-- a course-book like Head First Java (for a friendly and quick grasp of the big OOP concepts like polymorphism, etc.) -- Oracle JAVA tutorials -- in case some topic is not properly introduced or the student needs in-depth understanding then recommend to read the same in Head First Java or look it up online. Do not proceed until that point is clear. -- best way to do this course is to re-work each and every program that Tim is writing. In case you are a middle-level learner then maybe initial examples can be skipped. But as soon as you perceive complexity, do not wait for Tim to give you an exercise. Start coding right away. In case you are absolute beginner to programming then this course does proceed at a rate faster than you can cope with. My recommendation to proceed with these steps before you start this course:-- Do some mathematical level exercises based on JAVA such as print this or that star pattern. -- Same can be done in C or C++ but why to take the road on which you will not travel? -- Some examples: Print Fibonacci series till given number, 'n'. Print Newton's triangle. -- Sort an inputed list in ascending/ descending order. Try to write a program which solves an inputed Sudoku puzzle of the lowest complexity. -- Try to write a program to print a magic square. -- idea is that if you reach till this level then you are fully in command of 'if', 'for' and 'while' loop statements. These are the very basics of thinking like a computer. -- my recommendation would be to write the program on a piece of paper and literally dry-run it. I.e. your brain becomes the compiler and you run through each line of code following the control flow. That is how I learnt. Once you reach this complexity then read the beginning chapters of the ORACLE JAVA tutorials available at Oracle website. Understand what a class is and what an object is. What is state and behaviour. What are fields, etc. Just the basic grammar of Object Oriented Programming. Tip: sometimes you want to skip the boring text and look at animations or great explanations on YouTube in case the text-book theory is putting you to sleep. Whenever that happens a great strategy is to simply look for the topic on YouTube. Once you have reached to this level, that means that you very well know how conditional statements work and know what is meant by Class & Object. Now you are ready to take Tim's course. :) Thank you Tim. I cannot thank you enough.

For instance, in the set and hashset  section, Tim should have said directly that set is simply just a generic list that forbids duplicated items, and demonstrated some of its basic methods and features using an extremely simple example. comment: While most of the things are correct conceptually, the actual details of how things work under the hood are not exactly as explained which is confusing sometimes. Sometimes explanations are plain wrong.For example, when the new item is added to the stack, the ones that are added before are not really moving anywhere. Only the stack pointer is updated. This might seem insignificant, but this is actually why stack is so fast and efficient.Using unmodifiableCollection does not protect us from modifying Customer instances. Using CustomerReadOnly interface to avoid modifying the state of Customer instance is not an appropriate solution, in my opinion. I would say there is really no reason to make Customer mutable in the first place.Example explaining string immutability is irrelevant. String is immutable because it has no methods that modify its private state. The example is just re-assigning the reference to the string object, that would not change any object, mutable or not.The motivation for using heap is explained in a very confusing way. The code example illustrates re-using objects across different scopes by passing the reference of that object to another method. There is no reason why you would not be able to re-use the object should it still be allocated on the stack in that case.When the process finishes, all the memory used by the process is released. No, you don't need to re-start the computer if you have leaked some memory in the process. This is fundamentally incorrect statement. No, memory leak does not compromise the integrity of the computer it is running on, and it is not a horrible thing. It just means you will eventually run out of memory and will be forced to restart the process.With concurrent GC it's marking that is concurrent. You still need to pause all threads when compacting the heap, since your references on the stack needs to be updated. So it's the opposite to what the instructor says.

comment: Author says, that list.add(One) and list.add(new String(One)) could be considered as equivalent definitions, but it's wrong. This definition implies, that One is actually the same object, as the new String(One). But if we take two listsl1.add(One) and l2.add(new String(One)) and compare object references l1.get(0) == l2.get(0), the actual result will be  false, because new String(One) and One are different objects on the heap. And if we add l1.add(One) and l2.add(One) and compare l1.get(0) == l2.get(0), we will obtain true result, because One and One are the same object in the string pool. So we cannot consider l1.add(One) and l2.add(new String(One)) as equivalents, it's a rude mistake.

I took off 1/2 star for technical reasons.  The author says the @ override is not needed and deletes it from the code several times.  Actually, the @ override makes the code more readable and safer because it immediately tells us that the method is inherited and is distinct from a method that's not inherited.  Methods that override other methods have certain restrictions--access modifiers, argument lists, return types, and more.  Without the @ override identification, a coder might not match the same number of patameters in the overriding method with the overridden method and break the code.

comment: About a third of the material covers topics like generics and exceptions which should be covered in a basic Java course, while the advanced topics are only covered superficially. Important subjects like Swing and JDBC are only given 15-20 minutes of lectures each!So if the material in Advanced Java Programming isn't particularly advanced, how about the programming? Unfortunately, this is very much at the basic level, with baby examples written in a single class in the default package. Each subject is covered in isolation and there is no attempt to combine and consolidate previous topics to create more interesting (or even useful) programs. A couple of the examples are unnecessarily convoluted and there are a few which contain clear mistakes.There are also silent edits in some of the videos where the lecturer shows some code which contains an error but which runs smoothly. Then the lecturer returns to the code, where the error has been magically corrected. Meanwhile the student who has been typing along has spent a lot of time trying to work out why their identical code doesn't even compile.The lecturer does not appear to be active in the course forum, where students have asked a number of questions.All in all, rather a disappointing course. Although I did learn quite a few things which seem as though they should be useful, I didn't learn very much about them. I found it difficult to maintain my interest and my only real motivation to keep going was to complete the course.

courseName: Advanced Java Programming
comment: I came to this course having completed the Infinite Skills Java Basics course, which I found to be an excellent introduction to the language. I enjoyed the style of learning provided by Infinite Skills and Udemy and was keen to develop the skills that I learned in the first course.I found that the initial chapters in this course followed on well from the introductory course and I especially enjoyed the introduction to Swing and Java GUIs. However, from this point the course went down hill for me. The Swing introduction turned out to be just that: an introduction. In fact, the instructor went over a very basic set of Swing features and then promptly moved on to cover an entirely new topic. The Swing features were not used again.This problem plagues the second half of this course. Advanced topics are introduced, given the most basic explanation with very few lines of supporting code and then forgotten, never to be used again. The only exception to this rule is with Applets, which the instructor seems to use where Swing tools might be more appropriate. There is also no explanation of how to actually build applets into web pages which, it turns out, is a rather complicated feat in itself. Also, this course makes very little use of separate classes in the programs. I find this astonishing, given that Java is an Object Oriented Language with such an emphasis on class usage.There are some chapters on this course that I came out of with no greater understanding than I had when I went in. To this day, I have virtually no concept of what a Java Bean is and where I would want to use one.I appreciate that Java is a vast topic and it would take hours of video tutorial to cover everything in more detail. In reality however, when you are paying $99 for a course you would expect to get you money's worth. Extensive Java tutorial books are available for half the price of this course and go into significantly more depth.Ideally, this course should be split into two or even three courses. The first half of the course should be expanded on and placed into an intermediate course. There should be a greater emphasis on Swing development (because what applications are command-line based these days, realistically?)The second half of the course would be better if it were offered as a separate course going into significantly more detail than is available here and there are multiple improvements that could be taken into account on top of this.All in all, I do not consider that this course offers good value for money. The first half of the course saves the whole thing from being worth a one or two star review.

But people want to use JEE because it scales better and supplies better means to separate the layers (view, business logic, data). I had expected strategies and best practices - at least in an appendix. Apart from loosely following the MVC pattern the course does not give useful info on how to architecture a real world JEE application. Fittingly this course lacks e. g. the topics of Enterprise Java Beans and Context Dependency Injection, and also does not even roughly describe the other elements of the complex JEE standard. IMO a total fail!It should also be mentioned that IMO the presentation of the lessons is lousy: most of the time the instructor speaks way to fast, scrolls around to fast, lets the discussed code in eclipse be hidden in a too small frame, does not show graphical overviews but only text, code and speech... it is unnecessarily exhausting to follow. Sadly the instructor does not seem to answer to the questions of students...Why still a score of 2 stars? Well, *if* someone is interested in building a web frontend using JEE, then some basics are shown here. *But* it would still be better to follow the more modern JSF route (which is not contained in this course) instead of going with JSP / Struts.

courseName: Java EE 7 A Practical Training Course From Infinite Skills
comment: I purchased this course in a bit of hurry as it was on sale. Turns out it was a bad decision. How can a course on JEE7 not talk about JSF, JPA or JTA? I know those topic themselves deserve separate attention, but at least a good introduction could be done. Otherwise why would you label this as a 'Training Course'? How can it be demonstrated without using a proper application server? Even though Tomcat supports web development, that's not really an application server - it doesn't provide facilities like CMT. I thought of not wasting time on reviewing rest of the course, but I doubt if JNDI has been introduced here. I don't see web services being introduced, explanation of WSDL or SOAP. The Java Beans component architecture, connector architecture - nothing is here. You don't write a single EJB in a training course for JEE7!! This course must be titled: Introduction to Web Development using JEE7. Except for the incorrect naming, I don't blame Infinite Skills for this. It's my mistake I bought it in a hurry. I don't mean any disrespect to the people involved in building the course. It must have taken good amount of effort to make it available for students and apparently a lot of people are benefiting from it. It's just that I know the basics and my expectations were not met - so I have to give a '2' rating. Hopefully others will be able to make an informed decision.
